kristy.fountain: I've been on a similar journey since I was in middle school. In my twenties, I thought I could pinpoint the trigger, or eliminate them. I'm seeking, and the anxiety is always debilitating and inconvenient, not only for me, but especially for others around me. I believe that the most important thing we can do is *seek understanding. Finding answers is it's own thing and maybe not even necessary. Hugging you.

It just didn't agree with me. I thought I was going to die. It was awful. My mom took them & was fine. Guess different bodies handle things differently. If you want your hair to grow fast a sublingual b-12 under your tongue once a week will turn you into rapunzel asap. But biotin almost killed me from anxiety.

alexkonold: Thank you for being so vulnerable. You are not alone in this frustrating cycle. It helps me to try not to figure out what “caused” it. fan.tesstic: Jen really, go and travel, see something you’ve never seem before. I had crazy anxiety for a year, I was unable to leave my house, stopped seeing friends, just unable to function really. And then I took a plane to Bangkok and traveled around for 3 months and it was after a couple of weeks that I was finally able to breathe again. To feel like my old self again. I found a new energy to go back home and deal with everything again. I’m not saying that traveling will ‘cure’ your anxiety or instantly makes you feel better BUT you’ll get out of your comfort zone, eat different things, walk a lot, swim, soak up sun and I believe that’s what you need to pause your anxiety and re-asses the situation.. (ps I am not a native English speaker so sorry for any mistakes but really, traveling to an unknown place could be what you need right now)
